creditline: Lent by the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City, Missouri, Bequest of Mrs. George H. Bunting Jr.
description: fan-shaped dish; square walls, three small feet, unglazed underside; interior bottom decorated by tall plants in foreground lower left and two birds flying above; impressed fan at interior bottom lower left corner
medium: Stoneware with underglaze iron oxide designs and copper oxide glaze
text: Kitao_ji Rosanjin is considered by many to be the premier Japanese potter of the twentieth century. He had already earned a reputation as a talented calligrapher when he became interested in tableware through his association with the renowned Tokyo restaurant, Hoshigaoka. He experimented widely with traditional styles, and was incredibly adept at reproducing the spirit of historic ceramics. At the same time, he was also inventive, decorating some of his works in a distinctly modern manner. Here, Rosanjin based his design on a type of ceramic originally championed by the tea master Furuta Oribe (1544-1615) which featured innovative shapes irregularly decorated by dipping a portion of the form into a glaze mixture. After firing, these brilliant, grass green areas contrasted nicely with whimsical paintings in iron brown.
title: (Fan-shaped Plate)
